Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SWIFT: SMALL: Understanding and Combating Adversarial Spectrum Learning towards Spectrum-Efficient Wireless Networking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The next-generation wireless network is expected to be efficient, reliable, secure and spectrum-intelligent to maximize the efficiency of using the wireless spectrum. Dynamic spectrum access and management designs have shown their potential to substantially improve the spectrum utilization efficiency. To achieve the goal of securing efficient spectrum access and utilization, it is common in wireless network systems to collect and use spectrum reports from individual nodes to detect malicious behaviors and/or eliminate attack impacts. The goal of this project is to understand the potential strategies and impacts of a new attack, called adversarial spectrum learning, which aims to learn from the wireless spectrum data and construct specific attack models against spectrum management systems to disrupt the network performance. The project will also provide effective countermeasure against adversarial spectrum learning.

The project will focus on studying important research problems associated with adversarial spectrum learning via analytical modeling, comprehensive simulations, and experimental evaluations. Specifically, the research team aims at (i) formulating the adversarial spectrum learning strategies that can be used by malicious attacks to disrupt the spectrum efficiency and evaluating their damaging impacts in varying wireless and network conditions; (ii) detecting adversarial spectrum learning attacks via new non-parametric detection methods; (iii) creating attack prevention and secure management methods for secure and efficient spectrum access in the potential presence of adversarial spectrum learning, and (iv) comprehensively evaluating the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed detection and prevention strategies. Appropriate elements from the project will also be integrated into educational materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is focused on analyzing, modeling, detecting, and counter-reacting adversarial spectrum learning attacks in wireless networks. Unlike conventional wireless network attacks, adversarial spectrum learning takes advantage of the open nature of wireless information exchange and aim to use a substitute machine learning model based on spectrum sensing inputs and spectrum allocation outputs to learn a spectrum decision process. In this way, it can launch effective attacks against the decision process and inject malicious data to influence the eventual decision. The project uses theoretical modeling, simulations, and experimental data evaluation to understand adversarial spectrum learning and its defense. The objectives include formulating the adversarial spectrum learning strategies that can be used by malicious attacks to disrupt the spectrum efficiency, detecting, mitigating, and combating adversarial spectrum learning, and creating adversarial learning-aware spectrum management strategies in the potential presence of adversarial spectrum learning.

The project includes three major research tasks. 1) A comprehensive adversarial machine learning based attack model, called adversarial spectrum learning, against spectrum sensing in wireless networks is created and evaluated. The model is fully parameterized to set up different attack parameters and conditions to attack spectrum- intelligent network systems. 2) An efficient attack detection is comprehensively studied. The detection method is able to continuously monitor the spectrum data from network users and use a machine learning based metric to measure the user behavior statistics to identify malicious attack behavior. The project also designs a long-term spectrum management system that takes into the account of potential adversarial spectrum learning attack behavior, efficiency management of spectrum sensing and allocation. 3) The project also contributes significantly to advancing the theory and application of multi-armed bandits (MAB) in adversarial environments, with strong ties to the challenges of adversarial spectrum learning. Key contributions include the development of the adversarial grouped linear bandits model, which integrates stochastic uncertainties and adversarial behaviors to enable robust, real-time detection of malicious actions in dynamic wireless environments and the introduction of the Block-structured Follow-the-Regularized-Leader (B-FTRL) algorithm, which optimizes decision-making under adversarial conditions.

The project has produced research results of publications in major academic conferences and journals. The research results have been widely disseminated at conferences, workshops, and seminars, and made available at the PIs’ website. Educational impacts include the introduction of course materials related to wireless spectrum efficiency and security in undergraduate and graduate classes at the University of South Florida, as well as the incorporation of bandits-based learning and optimization algorithms into convex optimization courses at the University of Miami.
